text:
Just a reminder that neurodiversity covers a lot of space, not all of it in the autism spectrum. 
There are a couple types of neurodiversity: innate (like autism) and acquired (like me, it was brought on by damage to the brain.)

text:
Very important thread.

Neurodiversity means you can't imagine the end product of a sequence of tasks and because you can't imagine the end you can't start.

Nobody has ever said this to me so clearly before and I can immediately apply it at work (e.g. document with lipsum text) https://t.co/1vL2fZ95r7

text:
Neurodiversity is the night sky, a billion billion stars out there each representing something interesting.

A neurotype, in this metaphor, is a constellation. It's a term for a group of stars that show up together.

Autism, ADHD, Bipolar, OCD -- these are neurotypes.

We are not disabled.

We need a whole-government approach to neurodiversity.

We need change.

#ActuallyAutistic

text:
PSA: if you are talking about Neurodivergent people (ie autistic, ADHD, OCD, BPD etc) then use "neurodivergent"...NOT "neurodiverse". 

Neurodivergent and neurotypical people all together represent "Neurodiversity". 

Individuals cannot be "diverse".

text: @YessicaYesOrNo Neurodivergent is not a euphemism for autism. It's a collective term for various types of neurodiversity, including autism. It's a useful term because it signals that the differences from others we experience are a matter of wiring and not moral or behavioral failurings.

text:
The symbol of Autism is a Golden Infinty.

A Rainbow infinity is the symbol of the Neurodiversity movement.

Puzzle pieces represent the belief that Autistic people are missing a fundamental aspect of humanity. It is therefore considered a hate symbol by the Autistic Community.

@palaeoconnor Ditto. My story parallels this as a neurodiverse human who discovered their neurodiversity recently as an adult: "oh, that's why..."

text: I have never felt more cared for, than by friends with mental illness and neurodiversity. people who society vilifies as incapable of basic human emotions, and who are stigmatised as people I shouldn't associate with because they are "fundamentally broken" in society's eyes.

text:
it is always strange to me to see people treat mental illness and neurodiversity (often conflated by these people) as a dehumanising thing which robs people of their agency and empathy.

it is so often not the case, and much more commonly the opposite.

text: @jnicolemorgan Neurodivergence refers to a range of disabilities (autism, OCD, dyscalculia, etc). Each of those is diagnosed differently, and some (like ADHD) do take "disruptiveness" into account. But the point of neurodiversity as a movement is that these are differences, not disorders.

text:
@BrineA5 @lindy_treece Because autistics have been stigmatized for decades.

In the '80s, Aspergers became a popular term for parents who didn't want their kids called "autistic." Then other less stigmatized terms arrived. I agree neurodiversity exists, but I am not neurodivergent. I'm autistic.
tokenized_text: <user> <user> because autistics have been stigmatized for decades . in the ' 8 0 s , aspergers became a popular term for parents who did not want their kids called " autistic . " then other less stigmatized terms arrived . i agree neurodiversity exists , but i am not neurodivergent . i am autistic .

text:
@dogearedlibrary @lindy_treece And I agree it can be helpful for talking about neurodiversity, but I'd rather be addressed individually by my actual disorder and not a blanket term. We don't refer to a gay man as an "LGBTQ+ man."

I don't like being called neurodivergent. I'm autistic.

" i do not like being called neurodivergent . i am autistic .

text:
I don't have ADD/ADHD, but I do parent a child with ADHD. 

I have friends who have the diagnosis. 

And I am aware that rates of ADD/ADHD are rapidly increasing. 

So I felt I needed to improve my knowledge of neurodiversity. 

Just to be a more useful person/parent.

text: @neological_cos @Archival_End @nephyrus The literal definition is 'differing in mental or neurological function from what is considered typical or normal'. So anything that isn't a 'normal function' is considered neurodiversity, including depression as it's not a normal function of certain reward centres in the brain.

text:
Kinetic + NT

NT's have a hard time understanding Neurodiversity on a fundamental level. By default they are going to see the Kinetic as unreliable and potentially dishonest. 

For a K/NT relationship to thrive and be health you need to accept that Kinetic Truth is valid.
